newsitem.title: UK: British supermarket targets fashion victims.
newsitem.headline: British supermarket targets fashion victims.

text.p: British supermarket chain ASDA Group plc said on Thursday that it was introducing "fashion police" to target people who pay too much for clothes as a promotion for its own-brand "George" range.
ASDA said anyone stopped would be issued with a "fine" in the form of a voucher offering 10 percent discount on George clothing purchases.
"Whether their clothes are poor value or in poor taste, anyone 'cautioned' can use the voucher to make their next George purchase even better value," a statement from the company said.

ASDA, known for its cheeky and innovative approach to supermarket retailing, said it was also setting up a telephone helpline for fashion victims or anyone who wanted to inform on one as "Britain's worst dresser."
"ASDA's fashion police will hit the streets of Britain next week, showing zero tolerance for anyone wearing expensive brands, sad socks or grotty ties," the company said.
George is ASDA's own-brand clothing range, set up with George Davis who worked with the Next fashion store chain.
ASDA said George clothing was around 20 percent cheaper than that of its competitors.

ASDA said George sales were up 32 percent in the year ending May 3 as it reported pretax profits before exceptional items up 16 percent to 353.7 million pounds ($588.1 million) with a total dividend of 3.05 pence per share, up from 2.65 pence.
